awd_titl_txt: RAPID: A Panel Study of Presidentialism and, Democratic Collapse and the Rise of a One-Party State: Turkey at the Crossroads
awd_abstract_narration:
General Summary

This study assesses core questions about the role of political parties and political party members in the constitutional change of a parliamentary government system to a presidential governmental system in the aftermath of two strategic elections. The PI proposes to re-survey parliamentary candidates in the aftermath of parliamentary elections in which the majority party could not achieve a coalition to form a government. The new elections created a unique opportunity to assess and reassess the incentives that influence individual party members to support or oppose a transformation from a parliamentary system to a presidential system. Existing theories hypothesize that elite preference for presidential systems stems from the political insecurity of ruling party elites and, ideological and policy radicalization among all political elites. The PI examines how the characteristics of political parties influence how political-party elites account for the preferences of their party, their voters and special interest groups in reaching their decisions. Using Turkey as the case of interest, the PI re-interviews 300 MP candidates to create a novel panel dataset. 

Technical Summary

In this project, the PI collects elite-level survey data that allow her to test existing and new theories about strategic decision making concerning constitutional and regime change. Extant research in the literatures on political institutions and democratic collapse identify the insecurity of ruling party elites regarding their grip on political powers, ideological and policy radicalization among elites and structural factors such as poverty and ethnic polarization as key determinants influencing elites to choose a presidential over parliamentary system and, to support a transition to a non-democratic regime. However, recent empirical trends towards legislating constitutional changes to facilitate transitions to presidentialism and to non-democratic regimes suggest that existing explanations under-theorize the role of political parties in these phenomena. Compiling a novel elite panel dataset, the PI collects otherwise unavailable elite-level data through a re-survey of parliamentary candidates in Turkey. Through this elite-survey project the PI seeks to understand the incentive structure for both majority-party and opposition-party MP candidates in the parliamentary/presidential transition question. This research addresses literature on parliamentarism versus presidentialism, extension of presidential term of office, and creeping authoritarianism.

por.por_cntn:
This study proposed testing two sets of questions: (a) what influences political elites to support or oppose a transformation from a parliamentary democracy to a presidential democracy and, (b) how do characteristics of democratic party organizations and elites and, structural international factors influence political elites in a democracy to support or oppose a transition to a non-democratic one-party state. Three factors in particular were the focus on attention – individual characteristics of elites, characteristics of political party organizations and ethnic identity.  To study support for democracy, I proposed examining political support for key democratic institutions, practices and values including judicial independence, media independence, protection of civil liberties, support for changing political systems to a presidential system and to a one-party system among many other measures. The data for these analyses were to be collected via an elite survey of candidates before the November 2015 parliamentary elections and before the constitutional referendum to change Turkey’s political system from parliamentary to presidential in April 2017. These two rounds of surveys would add to the first round of this survey which was conducted in May, 2015. Both waves of the elite survey were successfully conducted realizing a final sample of 226 interviews for round 3 conducted in April 2017. All the analyses for these projects used these survey data in combination with census, election, economic and other publicly available data on Turkey.

To date, a substantial part of the analyses of the effects of party organizational characteristics, individual characteristics, interest group advocacy and, voters on selected aspects of elite attitudes and preferences has been completed. With respect to parties, I have analyzed how the dependence of political elites on the party for their careers affects their support for presidential or parliamentary regime, internal party democracy, judicial independence, media independence and protecting the civil liberties of citizens. An elite’s personal political dependence their party is higher for those elites who have little personal or family political experience, few relationships with interest groups and little interaction with voters or personal recognition among voters. These analyses show that that among elites who are highly dependent on their parties, those that are members of religious parties are significantly less inclined towards supporting these democratic institutions and practices. Among elites who are highly independent of their parties, higher levels of personal religiosity and authoritarianism significantly reduce support for more democratic institutions, values and liberties. However, as highly religious elites gain more political experience and build personal relationships with voters and interest groups, they become more moderate in their views and are more supportive of democratic institutions and practices. Personal religiosity ceases to significantly influence their support for judicial independence, media independence and internal party democracy. Importantly, this is true for elites in religious and secular parties.  Belonging to a religious party however significantly reduces support for civil liberties, judicial independence and media independence but not internal party democracy. Furthermore, support for a presidential system in Turkey is highest among inexperienced, highly religious and highly authoritarian elites in any party.

Special interest groups representing religious and business interests are highly influential among elites in Turkey. Their influence is driven by the ability of these groups to shape public opinion, to mobilize voters and, to donate money.  In addition to influencing the policy positions of political elites on economic and social issues, these groups, which often hold conflicting views on the value of media and judicial independence, are able to significantly influence how much support political elites are willing to extend to building these institutions as independent institutions rather than politically supervised institutions whose functions should be circumscribed by elected officials. Given the centrality of strong, independent courts and media in theories of democratic consolidation, this suggests that policymakers and scholars need to pay close attention to the agendas, assets and actions of special interest groups in Turkey and on religious and business groups in particular.

Finally, ongoing analysis is studying the influence of a democratic shock (the June 2015 election results) and an autocratic shock (the 2016 military coup attempt) on the attitudes of the panel of elites present in all three waves. My goal is to understand which characteristics identify elites who reacted to these shocks by changing their preferences in the direction of further strengthening democratic institutions, liberties and values and which characteristics identify elites who reacted by changing their preference to further undermine democratic institutions, liberties and values.
